results.lineage_statement:
Oct 27, 2021 a new release of the catalogue was migrated to production. This release moved resource level metadata to  their resources, including BC Geographic Warehouse (BCGW) metadata, like object_name. 

See the BC Data Catalogue Webpage listed in the more info for What's New and links to the changelog.
results.name: bc-data-catalogue-content
results.notes: The BC Data Catalogue is the place to find B.C. Government data, applications and web services. Government ministries and many broader public sector agencies publish their data resources in the Catalogue.  This data can be used to make informed decisions and create opportunities for the benefit of all British Columbians.

organization.name: databc
organization.title: Data Systems and Services (DataBC)
organization.description:
[DataBC](http://www.data.gov.bc.ca/) helps the Province manage data as an asset. It enables public servants and citizens to share and use data. DataBC delivers on this mandate by providing leadership in : data governance and custodianship; data licensing; literacy and outreach; data cataloging; data provisioning; geographic data integration and management; location based services and web mapping applications.

**Data Custodian:** Eowynn Bosomworth

**Editor Approver** Corinne Bexson

results.name: protected-lands-access-restrictions
results.notes: Protected Lands access restrictions include if a BC Park, Ecological Reserve, Protected Area, Recreation Area or Conservancy Area have access or use restrictions applied. This includes full closures, partial closures, if inaccessible, and restrictions/permits are required. This dataset also includes if campfires are permitted, prohibited or banned.

details.column_comments: Is a system generated unique identification number.

Operational Records Classification System (ORCS) means the government-wide standard for classification, filing, retrieval, vital records and freedom of information and protection of privacy designations, and disposition scheduling of operational records.

Operational Records Classification System (ORCS) means the government-wide standard for classification, filing, retrieval, vital records and freedom of information and protection of privacy designations, and disposition scheduling of operational records.
Is the commonly used name for the areas designated under the related legislation.

Is a comma separated list of alias used for a protected lands designated under the related legislation, e.g., kdistsausk (K'distsausk/Turtle Point Conservancy). It may be a phonetic version of an Indigenous name; modified for omitted punctuation; or a previous park name before being renamed.
Is the common term to identify the type of preserve and the legislation under which it was established, e.g., Conservancy, Ecological Reserve, Park, Protected Area, Recreation Area.
Is the standard alphabetic code to identify the type of preserve and the legislation under which it was established, e.g., PK (Park) was established under the Park Act.
Defines the different access status or states for a protected lands restiction, e.g., full closure, partial closures, inacessible, open.
Provides additional details associated with the access status type.
Defines the different type of event associated with a protected lands area restriction, e.g., avalanche, cultural, flood, landslide, tsunami, weather, wildfire, wildlife.

Indicates if campfires are defined as an available facility or not, i.e., Y, N. Additional restrictions may be applied like limiting burning hours. Always confirm any restrictions before visiting a protected lands area.
Indicates if there is an active campfires ban, i.e., Y, N. Always refer to the provincial campfire ban status for a Fire Centre before visiting a protected lands area.
Represents the BC Wildfire Service Centre administrative area name.
Represents the BC Wildfire Service Centre administrative zone name.
Indicates if the Fog Zone is part of the protected lands area. e.g, Y, N.
Is the date the protected lands access status type was effective.
Is the date the campfire ban was effective. Always refer to the provincial campfire ban status for a Fire Centre before visiting a protected lands area.
Contains the provincial region boundary name officially approved by BC Parks.
Contains the section name uniquely identifying Sub Region management areas within BC Parks Region boundaries, e.g., Okanagan.
Contains the manamement area name, e.g., West Okanagan.

Contains the search area name uniquely identifying geographically contiguous areas within the Provincial Parks and Protected Areas (BC Parks) Region boundaries, based on BC Parks Sections, e.g., North Island, Haida Gwaii.
The name of the Natural Resource District, e.g., Selkirk District.
Is the link to the Order with the details of the restriction or closure.
Is the link to the parks information bulletin.
Is the specific park website url.
Is the link to the map.
Is the system calculated area of a two-dimensional polygon in square meters.
Is the system calculated length or perimeter of a geometry in meters.
Is the column used to reference the spatial coordinates defining the feature.
Is a column required by spatial layers that interact with ESRI ArcSDE. It is populated with unique values automatically by SDE.
Is a binary column used by spatial tools to store annotation, curve features and CAD data when using the SDO_GEOMETRY storage data type.

results.name: bc-wildfire-fire-perimeters-current
results.notes:
Wildfire perimeters for the current fire season, including both active and inactive fires, supplied from various sources.   The data is refreshed from operational systems every 15 min.  These perimeters are rolled over to Historical Fire Polygons on April 1 of each year

Wildfire data may not reflect the most current fire situation, and therefore should only be used for reference purposes. Wildfire data is refreshed when practicable and individual fire update frequency will vary. The information is intended for general purposes only and should not be relied on as accurate because fires are dynamic and circumstances may change quickly.

organization.name: bc-wildfire-service
organization.title: BC Wildfire Service
organization.description:
The BC Wildfire Service is internationally recognised as a leader in wildfire management and is known for its skilled and committed personnel, uncompromising safety attitude, and innovative use of technology.

British Columbia’s forests and wildland cover over 94 million hectares (nearly a million square kilometres) and are the most diverse in Canada. Confronted by an average of 2,000 wildfires each year, highly trained fire crews are successful in containing 94 percent of all wildfires (rank 1-4) in B.C. by 10am the following day.

Custodian: Ian Meier
Delegate: Devona Hay

results.purpose: The information is intended for general purposes only and should not be relied on as accurate because fires are dynamic and circumstances may change quickly.

results.notes: The data contained within this spatial layer is an amalgamation of information for trails, Sites, Reserves, and Interpretive Forests derived from Forest Tenure Administration (FTA). The point is derived from the coordinates linked to each  recreation number example ( REC1567 ). That coordinate will identify either the trail head or the camping location or access  point to the area. Larger areas will be a central point to the polygon. http://www.sitesandtrailsbc.ca/closures.aspx

details.column_comments: Is a system generated unique identification number.
File identification assigned to Provincial Forest Use files. Assigned file number. Usually the Licence, Tenure or Private Mark number.
A common name given to a recreation site or trail, e.g. CAMPBELL LAKE, GRAY CREEK TRAILS.
The project type code, eg inventory
A combination of the project type code and the project type text, e.g. SIT -  Recreation Site.
Date on which the project was legally established.
Indicates if the location is closed or not, i.e., Y, N.
The user-entered date on which the Closure comment was entered.
Indicates the reason for the closure, e.g., Floods, Wildfire, Wind Damage, Wild Life, No Access, Slide Land/Snow, Industrial Work, Environmental, Other.
Indicates whether a Recreation project must be shown in the Recreation View web mapping toole, i.e., Y and N.
The current status of the forest land use, e.g., Pending - Planned, Harvesting - Suspended, Active. This is a subset of Timber_Status_Code.
The status of the forest land use code and description, e.g., HI - Issued.
Is the location name e.g. North side of Bentick Arm between Mohan and Campbell Lake.
Is a count of the total number of campsites in the recreation site.
Indicates if an archaelogical impact assessment has been performed for the given project.
A code that describes a significant land or environmental condition of the area, e.g., A2 (Aquatic Habitat), B2 (Sand Beach).
A combination of the Feature code and a textual description of the code, e.g., B2 - Sand Beach.
Administrative recreation district code for the Recreation site, e.g., RDPG.
Administrative recreation district name for the Recreation site, e.g., Prince George-Mackenzie.

Identifies any office within the ministry. First character identifies Exec, HQ branch, Region, or District.  Next two chars identify the office name; next two the section (HQ Branch) or program (Region or District); last char identifies the subsection.
Is the title of a ministry office or section; for example Kamloops Forest Region; Silviculture Branch; Kispiox Forest District P rotection program.
A text description generally describing the location of a recreation site. e.g. North side of Bentick Arm between Mohan and Campbell Lake.
Is the total area of a polygonal feature of a Tenure Applicaton in Hectares.
Is the total length for a linear feature of a Tenure Application in KM.
Comment about closures information about a recreation site or trail.
Comment about descriptive information about a recreation site or trail.
The user-entered date on which the Site Description comment was entered.
Comment about driving directions information about a recreation site or trail.
The user-entered date on which the Driving Directions comment was entered.

Is a segment of the Earth's surface 6 degrees of longitude in width. The zones are numbered eastward starting at the meridian 180 degrees from the prime meridian at Greenwich. There are five zones in BC (7 to 11), e.g., 10.
Is the distance in meters eastward to or from the central meridian of a UTM zone with a false easting of 500000 meters.
Is the distance in meters northward from the equator.

details.column_comments: Is a system generated unique identification number.

Operational Records Classification System (ORCS) means the government-wide standard for classification, filing, retrieval, vital records and freedom of information and protection of privacy designations, and disposition scheduling of operational records.

Operational Records Classification System (ORCS) means the government-wide standard for classification, filing, retrieval, vital records and freedom of information and protection of privacy designations, and disposition scheduling of operational records.
Is the name of the protected lands area.

Is a comma separated list of alias used for a protected lands designated under the related legislation, e.g., kdistsausk (K'distsausk/Turtle Point Conservancy). It may be a phonetic version of an Indigenous name; modified for omitted punctuation; or a previous park name before being renamed.
Is the common term to identify the type of preserve and the legislation under which it was established, e.g., Conservancy, Ecological Reserve, Park, Protected Area, Recreation Area.
Is the standard alphabetic code to identify the type of preserve and the legislation under which it was established, e.g., PK (Park) was established under the Park Act.
Defines the access status or state for a protected lands restriction, e.g., full closure, partial closures, inacessible, open.
Provides additional details associated with the access status or the access alert status.
Defines the type of event associated with the protected lands area restriction, e.g., avalanche, flood, landslide, tsunami, weather, wildfire, wildlife, cultural.

Indicates if campfire facilities are available in the protected lands area, i.e., Y, N. Additional restrictions may be applied such as limiting burning hours. Always confirm any restrictions before visiting a protected lands area.
Indicates if there is an active campfires ban, i.e., Y, N. Always refer to the provincial campfire ban status for a Fire Centre before visiting a protected lands area.
Represents the BC Wildfire Service Centre administrative area.
Represents the BC Wildfire Service Zone administrative area.
Indicates if the Fog Zone is part of the protected lands area. e.g, Y, N.
Is the date the protected lands access status type was effective.
Is the date the campfire ban was effective. Always refer to the provincial campfire ban status for a Fire Centre before visiting a protected lands area.

Contains the section name uniquely identifying Sub Region management areas within the Provincial Services Branch (BC Parks) Regions, e.g., Okanagan.
Contains the management area name, e.g., West Okanagan.

Contains the search area name uniquely identifying geographically contiguous areas within the Provincial Parks and Protected Areas (BC Parks) Region boundaries, based on BC Parks Sections, e.g., North Island, Haida Gwaii.
The name of the Natural Resource District, e.g., Selkirk District.
Is the link to the Order with the details of the restriction or closure.
Is the specific park website URL.
Is the link to the parks information bulletin.
Is the link to the map.

Is a required attribute of feature classes and object classes in a geodatabase.
A binary column used by spatial tools to store annotation, curve features and CAD data when using the SDO_GEOMETRY storage data type.

results.name: bc-wildfire-fire-locations-current
results.notes:
Wildfire location points for the current fire season.  This includes both active and inactive fires. Data is supplied through various sources and is updated from the operational systems every 15 minutes.     These points are rolled over to Historical Fire Points on April 1 of each year.

Wildfire data may not reflect the most current fire situation, and therefore should only be used for reference purposes. Wildfire data is refreshed when practicable and individual fire update frequency will vary. The information is intended for general purposes only and should not be relied on as accurate because fires are dynamic and circumstances may change quickly.

organization.name: bc-wildfire-service
organization.title: BC Wildfire Service
organization.description:
The BC Wildfire Service is internationally recognised as a leader in wildfire management and is known for its skilled and committed personnel, uncompromising safety attitude, and innovative use of technology.

British Columbia’s forests and wildland cover over 94 million hectares (nearly a million square kilometres) and are the most diverse in Canada. Confronted by an average of 2,000 wildfires each year, highly trained fire crews are successful in containing 94 percent of all wildfires (rank 1-4) in B.C. by 10am the following day.

Custodian: Ian Meier
Delegate: Devona Hay

details.column_comments: A composite of the following fields: Zone, Fire ID and Fire Centre.
Represents the fiscal year, April 1 to March 31.
Describes the type of response an incident is receiving and is based on fire behaviour, potential risks and environmental factors.
The discovery date of the fire.
The date the fire is deemed out.
The control stage of the fire as of the last update, e.g, Under Control, Out of Control, Being Held, Out.
The suspected cause of the fire, e.g., Lightning, Person.
Represents the BC Wildfire Service Centre administrative area.
A subset of the BC Wildfire Service Centre administrative area.
A unique number, system-generated, within a fire year and fire centre.
Defines the type of incident that occured, e.g., Fire of Note, New, Modified/Monitored, Full Response.
The official name of the wildfire.

A description of the approximate fire location: IC must note how far and in what direction the wildfire is in relation to a geographic reference. Note: for Railroad fires, actual railroad mileage is iuncluded as part of the geographic information, e.g., Sallus Creek, 172 mile-marker on railroad.
The geographic coordinate, in decimal degrees (dd.dddddd), of the location of the feature as measured from the equator, e.g., 55.323653.
The geographic coordinate, in decimal degrees (-ddd.dddddd), of the location of the feature as measured from the prime meridian, e.g., -123.093544.
The estimated size of the area within the outside perimeter of the incident, in hectares.
The unique link to the fire details page for this fire.
Indicates that the fire is currently a fire of note. Allowable values are Y for yes and N for no.
Indicates that the fire was a fire of note at some point during the fire season. Allowable values are Y for yes and N for no.
Contains an alphanumeric value based on the Canadian Council of Surveys and Mappingâ€™s (CCSM) system for classification of geographic features, e.g., AR82000110.

A binary column used by spatial tools to store annotation, curve features and CAD data when using the SDO_GEOMETRY storage data type.

resources.object_table_comments: Contains coordinate locations of current/active fire incidents. The data contains the spatial representation of the location coordinate point where the incident is occuring, zone information, and a geographic description.
resources.supplemental_info: Click Access/Download in the toolbar to download the KML Ground Overlay file. For more information see [Web Mapping Services](https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content?id=95D78D544B244F34B89223EF069DF74E).

details.column_comments: A composite of the following fields: Zone, Fire ID and Fire Centre.
Represents the fiscal year, April 1 to March 31.
Describes the type of response an incident is receiving and is based on fire behaviour, potential risks and environmental factors.
The discovery date of the fire.
The date the fire is deemed out.
The control stage of the fire as of the last update, e.g, Under Control, Out of Control, Being Held, Out.
The suspected cause of the fire, e.g., Lightning, Person.
Represents the BC Wildfire Service Centre administrative area.
A subset of the BC Wildfire Service Centre administrative area.
A unique number, system-generated, within a fire year and fire centre.
Defines the type of incident that occured, e.g., Fire of Note, New, Modified/Monitored, Full Response.
The official name of the wildfire.

A description of the approximate fire location: IC must note how far and in what direction the wildfire is in relation to a geographic reference. Note: for Railroad fires, actual railroad mileage is iuncluded as part of the geographic information, e.g., Sallus Creek, 172 mile-marker on railroad.
The geographic coordinate, in decimal degrees (dd.dddddd), of the location of the feature as measured from the equator, e.g., 55.323653.
The geographic coordinate, in decimal degrees (-ddd.dddddd), of the location of the feature as measured from the prime meridian, e.g., -123.093544.
The estimated size of the area within the outside perimeter of the incident, in hectares.
The unique link to the fire details page for this fire.
Indicates that the fire is currently a fire of note. Allowable values are Y for yes and N for no.
Indicates that the fire was a fire of note at some point during the fire season. Allowable values are Y for yes and N for no.
Contains an alphanumeric value based on the Canadian Council of Surveys and Mappingâ€™s (CCSM) system for classification of geographic features, e.g., AR82000110.
The column used to reference the spatial coordinates defining the feature.
A column required by spatial layers that interact with ESRI ArcSDE. It is populated with unique values automatically by SDE.
A binary column used by spatial tools to store annotation, curve features and CAD data when using the SDO_GEOMETRY storage data type.

details.column_comments: RAILROAD CROSSING ID is a  system generated identifier to ensure row uniqueness. This is a primary key field.
CHRIS RAILROAD CROSSING ID contains the identifier of the railroad crossing inventory item derived by the CHRIS application. E.g., 2422439
ADMIN UNIT CODE contains the MoT Service Area identifier. There are 28 service areas in MoT's jurisdiction. Each Service Area represents a geographic area within the province.  E.g., 13

ADMIN UNIT NAME contains the MoT Service Area Name identifier.  There are 28 service areas names in MoT's jurisdiction. Each Service Area Name represents a geographic area within the province.  E.g.,  Lower Mainland
CROSS SECTION POSITION contains the cross sectional position of railroad crossing in relationship to the road. E.g., Overhead - Left, Underpass - Left, Level etc.
CROSSING ID indicates the identification number of the crossing within railroad crossing information system. E.g., 196
CHRIS ANCHOR SECTON ID contains the CHRIS application internal unique identifier for the anchor section segment. E.g., 2777363
EVENT LOCATION contains the Measure for the Railroad Crossing along the Anchor Section. Measures are in Kilometers. e.g., 42.200
HIGHWAY NUMBER  is  the MoT Numbered Route identifier populated when the railroad crossing is located on a MoT Numbered route. E.g., 99
GEOMETRY is the column used to reference the spatial coordinates defining the feature.
OBJECTID is a required attribute of feature classes and object classes in a geodatabase.
SE_ANNO_CAD_DATA is a binary column used by spatial tools to store annotation, curve features and CAD data when using the SDO_GEOMETRY storage data type.

results.name: coastal-ferry-routes
results.notes: The locations of coastal ferry routes in British Columbia. This includes ferries in coastal waters like BC Ferries, barges, water taxis, etc. but does not include freshwater ferries on inland rivers or lakes.

organization.name: geobc
organization.title: GeoBC Branch
organization.description:
Custodian: Nancy Liesch
Delegate: Susan Westmacott

__GeoBC__ creates and manages geospatial information and products to help better manage natural resources in British Columbia. GeoBC also offers consultation services across all natural resource sector agencies.

__GeoBC__ has four areas of focus directly tied to natural resource business functions:
* Creating and maintaining a standard set of base spatial data that is open and accessible
* Providing direction and assurance for provincial land registries
* Offering Crown land and resource research expertise to other government agencies
* Delivering a service for custom solutions to natural resource business issues

results.purpose: To show the locations of all ferry routes in coastal British Columbia waters that will aid in the planning and support for emergency response along the coast.
results.title: Coastal Ferry Routes

resources.object_table_comments: A FERRY ROUTE is a line that represents the route a marine vessel follows while carrying passengers, freight or vehicles from one destination to another.
resources.supplemental_info: Click Access/Download in the toolbar to download this dataset. For more information on using the distribution order form see [How to download data using the Catalogue or iMapBC](https://bcgov.github.io/data-publication/pages/dps_data_distribution_w.html). If the data is visible through public WMS, click the Preview button on the toolbar.

details.column_comments: FERRY ROUTE ID is the unique Identifier for a particular ferry route. This is a primary key, e.g., 1,2,3

ROUTE NAME is a mandatory textual description of the two (or more) locations between which the ferry travels. In some cases, the ROUTE NAME is also an indication of the type of ferry service offered, e.g., North Thormanby Island Water Taxi, Swartz Bay - Fulford Harbour
MANIFEST TYPE is a textual description of the type of cargo carried by the ferry, e.g., passenger, freight, vehicle, passenger and freight, all
ROUTE OPERATOR is the name of the company or corporation that is responsible for the daily operation of the ferry, e.g., BC Ferries, Van Isle Barge Services Ltd.

ROUND TRIP USAGE is an estimate of the number of MANIFEST TYPE units that are ferried back and forth (round trip) from one starting point on the route to the other end of the route and back to the starting point. So, for example, if the ROUND TRIP USAGE is 1350 and the MANIFEST TYPE is "freight and vehicles", this means that this FERRY ROUTE transports 1350 freight and vehicles per round trip. Some of the ferry routes that support higher traffic have more than one ferry on the route. One ferry starts at one end and the other ferry starts at the other end. The ROUND TRIP USAGE for higher traffic routes is the combined total units tranported by all the ferries on the route, e.g., 1350
FREQUENCY OF USE IND is a textual indication of the usage load of the ferry. FREQUENCY OF USE IND will be one of the following: Very Low, Low, Moderate, High, Very High, Unknown.
DATA SOURCE is an indication of the source of the information used to place the FERRY ROUTE linework, e.g., Digital Road Atlas
GEOMETRY is the column used to reference the spatial coordinates defining the feature.
OBJECTID is a required attribute of feature classes and object classes in a geodatabase.
SE_ANNO_CAD_DATA is a binary column used by spatial tools to store annotation, curve features and CAD data when using the SDO_GEOMETRY storage data type.
FEATURE_LENGTH_M is the system calculated length or perimeter of a geometry in meters
